topic_name: Human Eye and the Colourful World

canonical_explanation.text: The human eye is a natural optical instrument that uses a convex lens (the eye lens) to form a real, inverted, and diminished image on the retina. The ciliary muscles change the shape (and focal length) of the lens to focus on objects at different distances — this ability is called the power of accommodation. The near point of a normal eye is 25 cm, and the far point is at infinity. Defects of vision include myopia (corrected by concave lens), hypermetropia (corrected by convex lens), and presbyopia (corrected by bifocal lens). When white light passes through a glass prism, it splits into seven colours (VIBGYOR) — this is dispersion. Atmospheric refraction causes twinkling of stars and early sunrise/delayed sunset. Scattering of light by small particles explains why the sky is blue (Tyndall effect) and why the sun appears reddish at sunrise and sunset.
rules: The eye lens is a convex lens that can change its focal length.
Power of accommodation allows the eye to focus on near and far objects.
Near point of normal eye = 25 cm; far point = infinity.
Myopia: distant objects not clear; corrected by concave lens.
Hypermetropia: nearby objects not clear; corrected by convex lens.
Presbyopia: occurs with ageing; corrected by bifocal lens.
Dispersion: splitting of white light into component colours (VIBGYOR).
Scattering of shorter wavelengths (blue) is more than longer wavelengths (red).
Sky appears blue due to scattering of blue light by atmospheric particles.

questions.question_text: The human eye forms an image on the:
questions.explanation_correct: The retina is the screen of the eye where the image is formed. It contains light-sensitive cells (rods and cones) that convert the light energy into electrical signals, which are sent to the brain via the optic nerve.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The cornea is the outermost transparent layer. The iris controls the size of the pupil. The pupil is the opening through which light enters. The image is formed on the retina, which acts as a screen at the back of the eye.

questions.question_text: The ability of the eye lens to adjust its focal length is called:
questions.explanation_correct: The ability of the eye lens to change its focal length by adjusting its curvature with the help of ciliary muscles is called the power of accommodation. This allows the eye to focus on objects at different distances.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Persistence of vision refers to the ability of the eye to retain an image for a short time after the object is removed. Dispersion and scattering are optical phenomena unrelated to the eye's focusing ability. The correct term is power of accommodation.

questions.question_text: The least distance of distinct vision for a normal eye is:
questions.explanation_correct: The least distance of distinct vision (also called the near point) for a normal human eye is 25 cm. At this distance, a person with normal vision can see objects most comfortably without straining the eye.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The near point of a normal eye is 25 cm, not 15 cm, 50 cm, or infinity. Infinity is the far point of the normal eye, not the near point. Objects closer than 25 cm cannot be focused clearly by a normal eye.

questions.question_text: Which part of the eye controls the amount of light entering it?
questions.explanation_correct: The iris is the coloured part of the eye that controls the amount of light entering the eye by changing the size of the pupil. In bright light, the iris contracts to make the pupil smaller, and in dim light, it expands to make the pupil larger.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The cornea is the transparent front surface of the eye. The retina is where the image forms. The optic nerve transmits signals to the brain. The iris is the structure that regulates the amount of light by adjusting the pupil size.

questions.question_text: When the ciliary muscles are relaxed, the eye lens becomes:
questions.explanation_correct: When ciliary muscles are relaxed, they pull the suspensory ligaments, which in turn stretch the eye lens making it thinner. A thinner lens has a larger radius of curvature and hence a longer focal length. This allows the eye to focus on distant objects.
questions.explanation_incorrect: When ciliary muscles relax, the lens becomes thinner (not thicker) with a longer focal length. This is the configuration for viewing distant objects. When the muscles contract, the lens becomes thicker for viewing nearby objects.

questions.question_text: Myopia is a defect of the eye in which a person cannot see:
questions.explanation_correct: Myopia (near-sightedness or short-sightedness) is a defect in which a person can see nearby objects clearly but cannot see distant objects clearly. The image of distant objects forms in front of the retina instead of on it.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Myopia affects the vision of distant objects, not nearby objects. A myopic person can see near objects clearly but distant objects appear blurred. This happens because the image forms in front of the retina.

questions.question_text: Myopia is corrected using a:
questions.explanation_correct: Myopia is corrected using a concave lens (diverging lens) of appropriate focal length. The concave lens diverges the light rays before they enter the eye, so that the image is pushed back onto the retina instead of forming in front of it.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A convex lens would make myopia worse by converging the rays further. A cylindrical lens is used for astigmatism. A bifocal lens is used for presbyopia. Myopia is corrected by a concave lens that diverges light rays.

questions.question_text: Hypermetropia is corrected by using a:
questions.explanation_correct: Hypermetropia (far-sightedness) is corrected using a convex lens (converging lens). The convex lens converges the light rays so that the image, which would otherwise form behind the retina, is brought forward onto the retina.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Hypermetropia requires a convex lens for correction, not a concave lens (which is for myopia), a plane mirror, or a concave mirror. The convex lens provides additional converging power to bring the image onto the retina.

questions.question_text: A person cannot see objects clearly beyond 1 m. This person suffers from:
questions.explanation_correct: If a person cannot see objects clearly beyond 1 m, the far point is at 1 m instead of infinity. This means the person is myopic (near-sighted). The image of distant objects forms before the retina because the eye lens is too thick or the eyeball is too long.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Since the person cannot see distant objects (beyond 1 m) clearly, this is myopia, not hypermetropia. In hypermetropia, the person cannot see nearby objects clearly. The far point being less than infinity is a sign of myopia.

questions.question_text: A person with myopia has a far point of 50 cm. The focal length and power of the corrective lens needed are:
questions.explanation_correct: For myopia correction, the concave lens should form a virtual image of a distant object at the far point. For an object at infinity (u = -infinity), image should be at v = -50 cm. Using lens formula: 1/f = 1/v - 1/u = 1/(-50) - 0 = -1/50. So f = -50 cm = -0.5 m, and P = 1/(-0.5) = -2 D.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A myopic eye needs a concave lens (negative focal length and power). The focal length equals the far point distance: f = -50 cm. Converting to metres: f = -0.5 m, so P = 1/(-0.5) = -2 D. A positive power would be for a convex lens used in hypermetropia.

questions.question_text: Presbyopia is caused by:

options.text: Excessive curvature of the eye lens
Gradual weakening of ciliary muscles with age

questions.explanation_correct: Presbyopia is an age-related defect of vision caused by the gradual weakening of the ciliary muscles and decreasing flexibility of the eye lens with ageing. This reduces the power of accommodation, making it difficult to see nearby objects clearly.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Excessive curvature of the lens or elongation of the eyeball cause myopia. Shortening of the eyeball causes hypermetropia. Presbyopia specifically results from the natural ageing process that weakens the ciliary muscles and makes the lens less flexible.

questions.question_text: The splitting of white light into its component colours is called:
questions.explanation_correct: The splitting of white light into its seven component colours (VIBGYOR) when it passes through a transparent medium like a glass prism is called dispersion. This happens because different colours have different wavelengths and are refracted by different amounts.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Reflection is the bouncing of light. Refraction is the bending of light. Scattering is the deflection of light by particles. The splitting of white light into its colours is specifically called dispersion.

questions.question_text: The correct order of colours in the spectrum from bottom to top (in a prism with base down) is:
questions.explanation_correct: When white light passes through a prism with its base downward, the spectrum produced shows violet at the bottom and red at the top. The order from bottom to top is VIBGYOR: Violet, Indigo, Blue, Green, Yellow, Orange, Red. Violet deviates the most and red the least.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The standard order of the spectrum produced by a prism (from the most deviated to least deviated) is VIBGYOR. Violet bends the most because it has the shortest wavelength, while red bends the least with the longest wavelength.

questions.question_text: Which colour of light deviates the most when white light passes through a glass prism?
questions.explanation_correct: Violet light deviates the most when passing through a glass prism because it has the shortest wavelength among the visible colours. Shorter wavelengths experience a greater change in speed (higher refractive index) and hence are refracted more.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Red light deviates the least because it has the longest wavelength. Violet, having the shortest wavelength, experiences the greatest refraction and hence the greatest deviation through a prism.

questions.question_text: Isaac Newton used a second identical prism placed inverted next to the first prism to show that:

options.text: The seven colours recombine to form white light
Light cannot pass through two prisms
Colours are absorbed by the second prism

questions.explanation_correct: Newton placed a second inverted prism in the path of the dispersed light. The second prism recombined all seven colours back into white light, proving that the prism only separates the colours already present in white light — it does not add any colour.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Newton's experiment with two prisms demonstrated that the seven colours produced by dispersion can be recombined to form white light. The second prism does not absorb the colours or block light — it recombines them.

questions.question_text: The apparent flickering of stars at night is due to:
questions.explanation_correct: Stars appear to twinkle due to atmospheric refraction. Starlight passes through different layers of the Earth's atmosphere with varying temperatures and densities. This causes the light to refract continuously, making the apparent position and brightness of the star fluctuate rapidly.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Stars twinkle because of atmospheric refraction, not because of nuclear reactions, reflection, or dispersion. The continuously changing atmospheric conditions cause the path of starlight to shift, creating the twinkling effect.

questions.question_text: The sky appears blue because:

options.text: The sea reflects blue colour to the sky
Shorter wavelengths of light are scattered more by atmospheric particles
The sun emits mostly blue light

questions.explanation_correct: The sky appears blue because atmospheric particles (mainly nitrogen and oxygen molecules) scatter shorter wavelengths of light (blue and violet) much more than longer wavelengths (red and orange). Since our eyes are more sensitive to blue than violet, the sky appears blue. This is explained by Rayleigh scattering.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The sky is not blue because air has colour, the sea reflects light, or the sun emits blue light. The blue appearance is due to the preferential scattering of shorter wavelengths (blue light) by small atmospheric particles — a phenomenon called Rayleigh scattering.

questions.question_text: The sun appears reddish at sunrise and sunset because:

options.text: The sun emits only red light at these times
Blue and shorter wavelengths are scattered away, leaving red light
The sun is cooler at these times

questions.explanation_correct: At sunrise and sunset, sunlight has to travel a much longer path through the atmosphere. During this long journey, most of the shorter wavelength blue light is scattered away in all directions, and the remaining light that reaches our eyes is predominantly red and orange, giving the sun a reddish appearance.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The sun does not change the light it emits at different times. The reddish appearance is because blue light is scattered away as sunlight travels a longer atmospheric path during sunrise and sunset, so mostly red light reaches our eyes.

questions.question_text: The Tyndall effect is observed when light is:
questions.explanation_correct: The Tyndall effect is the scattering of light by colloidal particles or particles in suspension. When a beam of light passes through a colloidal solution (like smoke, mist, or milk diluted in water), the path of light becomes visible due to scattering by the tiny particles.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Tyndall effect is not about reflection, refraction, or absorption. It is specifically about the scattering of light by very fine particles suspended in a medium, making the path of the light beam visible.

questions.question_text: We see the sun about 2 minutes before actual sunrise because of:
questions.explanation_correct: Due to atmospheric refraction, the light from the sun is bent downward as it passes through the atmosphere (from rarer to denser layers). This makes the sun appear slightly above its actual position. As a result, we see the sun about 2 minutes before actual sunrise and about 2 minutes after actual sunset.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The early visibility of the sun is due to atmospheric refraction, not dispersion, scattering, or total internal reflection. The atmosphere bends sunlight downward, causing the sun to appear higher than its actual position, giving us an apparent sunrise before the actual one.

questions.question_text: The image formed on the retina of the human eye is:
questions.explanation_correct: The eye lens (a convex lens) forms a real, inverted, and diminished image on the retina. The brain then processes this inverted image and interprets it as erect, so we see objects the right way up.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The image on the retina is real (formed by actual convergence of light rays), inverted (upside down), and diminished (smaller than the object). Our brain automatically flips this image so that we perceive things right-side up.

questions.question_text: A person who can see nearby objects clearly but cannot see distant objects clearly has a defect called:
questions.explanation_correct: The ability to see nearby objects clearly but not distant objects is the hallmark of myopia (near-sightedness). In myopia, the image of distant objects is formed in front of the retina because the eye lens is too converging or the eyeball is elongated.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This describes myopia, not hypermetropia (which makes nearby objects unclear) or presbyopia (an age-related condition). In myopia, the eyeball may be too long or the lens too curved, causing distant objects' images to form before the retina.

questions.question_text: A person with hypermetropia has a near point of 1 m. The focal length and power of the corrective lens needed to restore normal near point (25 cm) are:
questions.explanation_correct: The corrective convex lens must form a virtual image at 1 m (100 cm) of an object placed at 25 cm. Using lens formula: u = -25 cm, v = -100 cm. 1/f = 1/v - 1/u = 1/(-100) - 1/(-25) = -1/100 + 1/25 = -1/100 + 4/100 = 3/100. So f = 100/3 = +33.3 cm = +0.333 m. P = 1/0.333 = +3 D.
questions.explanation_incorrect: For hypermetropia correction, a convex lens is needed (positive f and P). The object at 25 cm should appear at 100 cm (the person's near point). Using the lens formula gives f = +33.3 cm and P = +3 D.

questions.question_text: The angle of deviation in a glass prism is minimum when:

options.text: The angle of incidence equals the angle of emergence
The light enters perpendicular to the surface
The prism has a very small angle

questions.explanation_correct: The angle of deviation of light passing through a prism is minimum when the angle of incidence is equal to the angle of emergence. At this position, the refracted ray inside the prism is parallel to the base of the prism, and the light passes symmetrically through the prism.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The minimum deviation condition occurs when the angle of incidence equals the angle of emergence, not when the incidence is 90° or perpendicular. At minimum deviation, the light ray passes symmetrically through the prism.

questions.question_text: Planets do not twinkle because:

options.text: They do not emit their own light
They are closer and appear as extended sources
Their light is not affected by the atmosphere

questions.explanation_correct: Planets are much closer to Earth compared to stars and appear as extended sources (small discs) rather than point sources. The light from different parts of the disc averages out the fluctuations caused by atmospheric refraction, so the overall brightness remains fairly steady and planets do not appear to twinkle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Planets do not twinkle because they appear as extended (disc-like) sources due to their relative closeness, not because they are too far or unaffected by the atmosphere. The averaging effect of multiple point sources across the disc cancels out the flickering.

questions.question_text: The far point of a normal human eye is at:
questions.explanation_correct: The far point of a normal human eye is at infinity. This means a normal eye can see objects at very large distances clearly. When viewing distant objects, the ciliary muscles are fully relaxed and the eye lens is at its thinnest.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The far point of a normal eye is infinity, not 25 cm (that is the near point), 1 m, or 50 cm. A person who cannot see objects at infinity clearly (far point less than infinity) suffers from myopia.

questions.question_text: A rainbow is formed due to:

options.text: Dispersion, refraction, and total internal reflection of light

questions.explanation_correct: A rainbow is formed by the combined effect of dispersion, refraction, and total internal reflection of sunlight by water droplets in the atmosphere. Light enters a water droplet, gets refracted and dispersed into different colours, undergoes total internal reflection inside the droplet, and then refracts again as it exits.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A rainbow is not formed by just one phenomenon. It requires refraction (bending at entry and exit), dispersion (separation into colours), and total internal reflection (inside the water droplet) working together.

questions.question_text: In myopia, the image of a distant object is formed:
questions.explanation_correct: In myopia, the image of distant objects is formed in front of the retina because the eye lens is too thick (converging power is too high) or the eyeball has become too long. The light rays converge before they reach the retina.
questions.explanation_incorrect: In myopia, the image forms in front of the retina, not on it or behind it. In hypermetropia, the image forms behind the retina. A concave lens is used to correct myopia by diverging the rays before they enter the eye.

questions.question_text: The colour that has the maximum wavelength in the visible spectrum is:
questions.explanation_correct: Red light has the maximum wavelength (about 620-750 nm) among all visible colours. Violet has the shortest wavelength (about 380-450 nm). The order of increasing wavelength is: Violet, Indigo, Blue, Green, Yellow, Orange, Red.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Red has the longest wavelength in the visible spectrum. Violet has the shortest. This is why red light deviates the least and violet deviates the most when passing through a prism.

questions.question_text: If the Earth had no atmosphere, the sky would appear:
questions.explanation_correct: If the Earth had no atmosphere, there would be no particles to scatter light. Without scattering, the sky would appear dark or black, as is observed from the moon (which has no atmosphere) or from space. The sun would appear as a bright disc against a black background.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Without an atmosphere, there would be no scattering of light, so the sky would appear black/dark. The blue colour we see is solely due to the scattering of sunlight by atmospheric molecules. This is why the sky appears dark from the surface of the moon.

questions.question_text: Which part of the eye changes its shape to focus on objects at different distances?
questions.explanation_correct: The eye lens changes its shape (curvature) with the help of ciliary muscles to focus on objects at different distances. When viewing nearby objects, the lens becomes thicker (shorter focal length), and when viewing distant objects, it becomes thinner (longer focal length).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The cornea, pupil, and retina do not change shape for focusing. It is the eye lens whose curvature is changed by the ciliary muscles to focus light from objects at different distances onto the retina.

questions.question_text: A person needs a lens of power -2.5 D for correcting vision. The person is suffering from:
questions.explanation_correct: A negative power (-2.5 D) indicates a concave (diverging) lens. Concave lenses are used to correct myopia (near-sightedness). The negative sign confirms the lens diverges light rays, which is needed to push the image back onto the retina in a myopic eye.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Negative power means a concave lens is needed, which is used for myopia correction. Hypermetropia requires a convex lens (positive power). The power of -2.5 D indicates the person is short-sighted (myopic).

questions.question_text: The near point of a normal human eye is 25 cm.
questions.explanation_correct: The statement is true. The least distance of distinct vision (near point) of a normal human eye is 25 cm. Objects placed closer than this distance cannot be focused clearly by the eye.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This statement is true. The near point of a normal human eye is indeed 25 cm, also called the least distance of distinct vision.

questions.question_text: Hypermetropia is corrected using a concave lens.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is false. Hypermetropia (far-sightedness) is corrected using a convex lens (converging lens), not a concave lens. The convex lens provides the additional converging power needed to bring the image onto the retina.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Hypermetropia requires a convex lens, not a concave lens. A concave lens is used to correct myopia. The convex lens helps converge the light rays so the image falls on the retina instead of behind it.

questions.question_text: Violet light has a higher wavelength than red light.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is false. Red light has the highest wavelength (about 620-750 nm) in the visible spectrum, while violet has the lowest (about 380-450 nm). The order of increasing wavelength is VIBGYOR.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Violet light has a shorter wavelength than red light, not a higher one. Red light has the maximum wavelength among visible colours, while violet has the minimum. This is why violet is deviated more than red by a prism.

questions.question_text: The danger signals are made of red colour because red is scattered the least by fog and smoke.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is true. Red light has the longest wavelength among visible colours and is scattered the least by atmospheric particles, fog, and smoke. This allows red light to travel the greatest distance without much loss, making it visible from far away. That is why danger signals, brake lights, and traffic stop signs use red colour.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This statement is indeed true. Red light is scattered least because of its long wavelength, allowing it to travel farther through fog, smoke, and atmospheric particles, making it ideal for danger signals.

questions.question_text: The eye lens is a concave lens.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is false. The eye lens is a convex lens (converging lens), not a concave lens. It converges the light rays entering the eye to form a real image on the retina. Its focal length can be changed by the ciliary muscles.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The eye lens is a convex lens, not concave. It converges light to form a real, inverted, diminished image on the retina. Its curvature (and hence focal length) is adjusted by ciliary muscles for focusing at different distances.

questions.question_text: A glass prism adds colours to white light during dispersion.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is false. A glass prism does not add any colour to white light. It merely separates the colours already present in white light. Newton proved this by recombining the dispersed colours back into white light using a second inverted prism.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The prism does not create or add colours. White light itself is composed of seven colours (VIBGYOR). The prism only separates these existing colours by refracting them by different amounts due to their different wavelengths.

questions.question_text: The ability of the eye to focus on objects at different distances is called the power of ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The power of accommodation is the ability of the eye lens to adjust its focal length by changing its curvature with the help of ciliary muscles, allowing the eye to focus on objects at different distances.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'accommodation'. The eye's ability to change the focal length of its lens to focus on objects at varying distances is specifically called the power of accommodation.

questions.question_text: Myopia is corrected by using a ___ lens.
questions.explanation_correct: Myopia (near-sightedness) is corrected using a concave (diverging) lens. The concave lens diverges the incoming light rays before they enter the eye, so that the image shifts back to fall exactly on the retina.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'concave'. A concave lens is used to correct myopia. It diverges the light rays to ensure the image of distant objects falls on the retina rather than in front of it.

questions.question_text: The band of seven colours obtained when white light passes through a prism is called a ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The band of seven colours (VIBGYOR) produced by the dispersion of white light through a glass prism is called a spectrum. This shows that white light is composed of lights of seven different colours.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'spectrum'. The band of colours produced by dispersing white light is called a spectrum. The visible spectrum consists of seven colours: violet, indigo, blue, green, yellow, orange, and red.

questions.question_text: The scattering of light by colloidal particles is known as the ___ effect.
questions.explanation_correct: The scattering of light by colloidal particles (particles that are larger than atoms but small enough to stay suspended) is known as the Tyndall effect. It makes the path of a light beam visible when it passes through a colloidal solution.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'Tyndall'. The Tyndall effect refers to the scattering of a beam of light by the fine particles in a colloid or suspension, making the light beam visible.

questions.question_text: The light-sensitive cells on the retina that detect colour are called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Cones are the colour-sensitive photoreceptor cells on the retina. There are three types of cones, each sensitive to red, green, or blue light. The combination of signals from these three types allows us to perceive all colours.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'cones'. The retina has two types of photoreceptors: rods (for dim light vision) and cones (for colour vision). Cones are responsible for detecting and distinguishing different colours.

questions.question_text: Presbyopia is corrected by using ___ lenses.
questions.explanation_correct: Presbyopia is corrected using bifocal lenses. The upper part of the bifocal lens is a concave lens for distance vision, and the lower part is a convex lens for near vision. This helps the person see both nearby and distant objects clearly.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'bifocal'. Presbyopia, which involves difficulty in seeing both near and far objects due to ageing, is corrected using bifocal lenses that combine concave and convex lenses in a single spectacle.

questions.question_text: The sky appears blue due to the ___ of light by atmospheric particles.
questions.explanation_correct: The blue colour of the sky is due to the scattering of sunlight by the tiny particles in the Earth's atmosphere. Blue light, having a shorter wavelength, is scattered much more than red light, making the sky appear blue.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'scattering'. The blue sky is a result of the scattering (specifically Rayleigh scattering) of shorter wavelengths of sunlight by atmospheric molecules.

questions.question_text: The transparent front layer of the eye through which light enters is called the:
questions.explanation_correct: The cornea is the transparent, curved front surface of the eye through which light first enters. It provides most of the eye's optical power by refracting the incoming light. After the cornea, light passes through the pupil and the eye lens before reaching the retina.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The iris is the coloured disc that controls pupil size. The lens is behind the iris. The retina is at the back. The cornea is the outermost transparent layer where light first enters the eye.

questions.question_text: Dispersion of light occurs because:

options.text: Different colours travel at the same speed in glass
Different colours have different speeds in glass

questions.explanation_correct: Dispersion occurs because different colours of light travel at different speeds in a transparent medium like glass. Since each colour has a different wavelength, it has a different refractive index in glass. Violet light slows down the most and red the least, so they are refracted by different amounts.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Dispersion does not occur because all colours travel at the same speed (they travel at different speeds in glass), or because colours are absorbed or reflected. It is the difference in speeds (and hence refractive indices) of different colours that causes them to separate.

questions.question_text: In hypermetropia, the image of nearby objects forms:
questions.explanation_correct: In hypermetropia (far-sightedness), the image of nearby objects forms behind the retina because the eye lens is too thin (converging power is too low) or the eyeball is too short. A convex lens is used to bring the image forward onto the retina.
questions.explanation_incorrect: In hypermetropia, the image of nearby objects forms behind the retina, not in front of it. This is the opposite of myopia, where the image forms in front of the retina. A convex lens provides additional converging power to correct this.

questions.question_text: An astronaut in space sees the sky as:
questions.explanation_correct: In space, there is no atmosphere to scatter light. Without atmospheric scattering, the sky appears black. Stars are visible as bright points against the dark background, and the sun appears as a bright disc without the blue scattered background we see from Earth.
questions.explanation_incorrect: In space, the sky appears black because there are no atmospheric particles to scatter sunlight. The blue colour of the sky we see from Earth is entirely due to atmospheric scattering, which is absent in the vacuum of space.

questions.question_text: The colour that is deviated the least by a prism is ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Red light is deviated the least by a prism because it has the longest wavelength and hence the lowest refractive index in glass. The longer the wavelength, the less the light bends when passing through a prism.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'red'. Red has the longest wavelength in the visible spectrum and therefore experiences the least deviation (bending) when passing through a glass prism. Violet, with the shortest wavelength, is deviated the most.
